text:
Poured from a 750 ml bottle. 
Aroma is very oxidized with lots of sherry character. Light funk and acidity. 
The cord on this was warped and slid right out with almost no friction. Pours a copper reddish color with a faint, forced head. 
Flavor has moderate acidity with hints of citrus and quite a bit of sweetness. Some red apple and tons of sherry notes. Faint funk, but its really not super present. 
Mouthfeel is medium bodied with no carbonation. Low astringency and low alcohol warmth. 
Overall, a bad beer; well, a bad bottle. Both of the previous bottles I have opened have been way better. The cork in this one looks like it was pushed out and then resettled. So much oxidation.

Hazed amber with a decent haze. Light balsamic and musty aroma. Like a balsamic acidic lollipop with a duller acidic finish. 

Notes: Bottled in 08 drank in 16. I bought this bottle at the 3 Fonteinen while living in Belgium in 09-11 and brought it back with me. It was aging ~6 more years before opening for a bottle share at Erics, Dec 16.

Sampled from 2008 750ml bottle and shared by thomas hall. Pours a hazy caramel yellow brown colored brew with a fast dissipating off-white head that leaves behind a film top. Aroma of brown sugar, caramel malt, a hint of dark pitted fruits and oak. Taste is medium bodied, no carbonation with flavors of powdered caramel malt, brown sugar and dark pitted fruits. Finish is neutral with some oxidation and light brown sugar aftertaste.

Carbonation is gone from this bottle. Brown color. A little sugar and some yeast. Rather than a faro, it is like a well balanced Belgian ale. Even though the palate suffers, it still
 Has good flavo.

Hazy dark amber pour with no head. No carbonation at all. Really nice nose a hint of funk and malty sweetness. Taste is nice but you must wonder what it would have been like when carbonated. Malty toffee and some funk.
Bomber shared by Tom - thanks! 2008 bottle shared in 2017. No pop on opening, yes, this went flat. Damn shame. Nice aroma, but the palate is thin and flat. Darn, wound love to try this in its prime.
75cl bottle shared at tasting. Caramel brown pour. Aroma is sugar and tart. Taste is flat, lost carbonation unfortunately. Wish I could try a good bottle of this. Bummer.
750ml bottle. 2008 Vintage. Poured a cloudy amber color with an off white head. Some sour fruits, spices, a bit funky, and citrus.

BB backlog, Bottle in 2013, think it was a 2008 vintage. Pours amber with small sized head. Notes of wet oak, lactic lemon, horse blanket, blackberry, sherry and light caramel. Pretty sour but also has some more belgian fruit notes. Body and carbonation were light to medium. Glad I was able to try this one but prefer gueuze.
Shared by Andy. No head, brown. So, guess its a good faro. Not to sweet and I guess there is Lambic. I like the Lambic but the sweetness is still weird. Sugar sour.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text:
750 mL bottle. Originally reviewed 9/20/2014.

Deep hazy orange. No head.

Smells kinda funky. Orange. Dry grass. A little lemony acidity.

Taste much more sour than I expected. Lemon. A bit of vinegar. Woody. Some deep brown sugar. A bit of oxidation.

Medium body. Medium carbonation. 

I thought this would be terrible, but its pretty good. Very sour.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2016 Köpt på Bishop Örebro. Brun- orange grumlig färg. Kryddig doft av jordkällare, cider och lagrad äppelmos. Mustig och kraftfull kropp. Lite kolsyra. Smak av syltade och torkade äpplen, sultanrussin, calvados, knäck, ekfat och vinäger. Kryddig och funky.
UPDATED: MAY 1, 2016 Flaska bishops 75 cl. Orangebrun vätska. Mustig doft av övermogna äpplen, russin och stall. Sötsyrlig smak av torkad frukt, kryddor, trä, citron och funk. Låg kolsyrehalt.

Bottle shared at DHVL. Hazy amber brown with a bubbly light tan head. Aroma is oxidized with big sherry notes, toffee, tart fruits and a light funk. Flavour is moderate sweet and sour, with very citric acidity in the finish. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Sample at the Heren van Liedekercke courtesy of Kermis. Vintage 2010
Thin white head. Cloudy amber pour. Tart sugary oxidised aftertaste.

Amber pour with VERY minimal off-white head. Thank you, Adam, for sharing this! Smells like a fake sweet cherry lollipop. Not loving this aroma. Mouthfeel is weak. But the flavor is good for what this is. While theres some sediment in this pour, this tastes like moldy cherry pie. Oxidation has definitely kicked in. Its still drinkable and pretty solid, overall. Given that this is a faro, Im going to be a bit more lenient with my rating...

(750ml 2008 bottle @ Delirium Cafe, July 27th 2015) Pours fairly clear iced tea colour with a small head of big bubbles and no lace. Aroma is like a hybrid of Flanders bruin and barley wine, sweet and tart with lots of dried fruit, especially prunes and figs and sweet grapes, fortified wine notes (moscatel or tawny port) give a vinous feel, fairly oxidized, oak and a slightly sulphurous funk in the background. On the palate, not nearly as sweet, with a big component of acetic acid for a lambic. Oxidized, moderately funky, crabapple and golden raisins, hints of caramel. Funk towards the finish, some sulphur, hint of mint, oaky. Light bodied with carb almost all gone. I think this had got a little past it (and perhaps not the best venue for handling...), nose promised more but the oxidation had got to the palate. Still quite interesting, would have been even better in slightly nicer condition.
Bottle thanks to Rick, pours a cloudy orange with small off white head. Aroma is bandaids,feet, and funk. Medium mouth with tart fruit and light funk, very good.

75cl bottle from 2008, pours red brown to amber, a little hazey. Small white head, quickly dissipating. This is a specialty lambic, closest to a faro since dark candi sugar was added, though the Lambic portion was untraditional using some amber and Munich malts. Wheat is its main ingredient. 8ABV, one time brew. Great sweet-sour balance, oak, lactic acid, earthy notes, lambic and dark candi. Also whiskey notes. Beautiful!

Bottle at S&G Tasting. Many many thanks to Mathieu87 for this bottle. Rating #2000.
APPEARANCE: clouded blond beer, small unstable white head.
NOSE: caramel, little sour.
TASTE: rather sweet, but very sour, some carbonation, very very nice faro! Aged quite amazing actually!

2008, 750 c&c from Bu11zeye. Pours hazy darkish brown with no head. Aroma is essentially elderly malt with spice notes. Med body. Flavor is woody, dark malt with slightly sourish fruits. Finishes a bit tart. Its great.

2008 bottle shared by bhensonb. Pours orange brown with no head and a dark fruit and brown sugar aroma. There is a sour fruit and brown sugar flavor, very mellow and tasty. Best faro I have encountered.

Specialty lambic from the winter of 2010 - 2011. Bottled faro is a weird concept to me which I usually associate with oversweetened, blended beers like Lindemans Faro, but when 3 Fonteinen does it, I put all my trust in it. Justly so, it turned out. The lambic used for this contains not only unmalted wheat and pale malts, but malted wheat, Munich malt and amber malt as well, very unusual for the style. What makes this a special faro instead of a special geuze, is of course the addition of candi sugar. Thin but stable head, warm orangey amber colour, misty. Complex, powerful aroma of lively fruity esters as in any good lambic, mandarin, fresh grape juice, sherry, hay, wood, lemon, cider, apple peel, caramel, candi sugar, toasted bread. Complex taste with a whole array of flavours the ardent lambic lover adores, including lactic acid, fresh citric acid, wine vinegar, sherry, wood, as well as an honest candi sugar sweetishness in the finish, a tea-like aspect and a long, dry finish of tannins, funkiness and tartness. Absolutely lovely.

Sample at Ölrepublikens surölsfestival. Hazy red brown with small off white head. Smell is sour with green apples, sweet candi sugar and syrup and funky with stables and horse. Taste is sweet and sour, quite well balanced. Sweet candi sugar with funky stables and sour.

Sampled at Where the Wild Beers Are, 6/7/14

Pours an amber color with a small off-white head. Fruit and wheat. Some wood notes. Nicely funky and enjoyable.

bottle shared by tom10101, many thanks bro! pours almost murky copper-red with a small off-white cap showing minimal retention and lacing. red berries, but also some yeloow fruits - sweetish peaches perhspa, oaky with a bit of cheese, very woody in fact, 3f-funk, hint of sweetness - maple syrup, vanilla, lo-fi caramel and candi. average carbonation - could be just a tad brighter, light body, relatively dry and lightly astringent grassy finish. nicest faro ive had by far - on the dry side of faros - say as sweet as girardins black label but less sweet than their white label..

140801, bottled 080125. Thanks tderoeck for sharing!
Pours cloudy orange/amber with a small off-white head. Aroma is light tart cherries, wood, citrus, oak and light/medium sweet sugary and malty. Taste is light sweet caramel, tart fruits, cherries, green apples. Finish is tart fruity, light caramel and very light bitter, Smooth, medium bodied.

1/VIII/14 - 75cl bottle from the brewery @ Belgo-Swedish Crazy Summer Trade Tasting - BB: I/2012, bottled: 25/I/2008 (2014-869) 
Little cloudy amber to red beer, creamy off-white head, irregular, unstable, bit adhesive, leaving a nice lacing at some places in the glass. Aroma: sweet touch, fruity, cherry notes, tannins, woody, lemony. MF: soft carbon, medium body. Taste: bit sweet, caramel, lemony, pretty sour, little bitter, some vinegar notes. Aftertaste: green apples, lemony, little bitter, grassy touch. Very rich flavours, complex yet soft and subtle. Lovely one this...

Bottle 750ml.
Pours hazy light brown with no serious head. Aroma is of caramel, sugar, malt, sourness. Taste is of caramel, tartness, sugar, apples, acetic notes. Palate: Light-medium body. Very soft carbonation. Overall: Better than your regular Faro. Surprisingly sour.
Bottle. Brown amber with very low head. Caramel, bugs, some lactic and acetic notes. Carbonation is very low which amplifies its faults. A rare miss by 3F.
Caramelly geuzey smell and taste. Like a geuzey St Lamvinus with a malt note.  Low-medium carbonation
WTWBA 2014. The aroma is very sweet, candi sugar. The appearance is brown/red. The flavor is sour, sweet, candi sugar. The finish is sweet, sour. Medium in body. Nice.

Taster from bottle pour. Deep amber. Not a lot of head. Sweet nose. Dark fruits. Juicy. Hint of vinegar. Crisp taste. Brett and lemon, balanced with caramel and leather. Complex, round flavors. Great execution.

bottle brought by max to WWBA bless your heart. pours brown with nose of ripe fruits and caramel. tastes sweet but only faintly of that weird fao sugar stuff. you also get plenty of toffee, reduced balsamic, figs, and leaves. funky finish and lingering sweetness. pretty awesome

Bottle at Grote Dorst. Not quite clear deep amber pour with thin white head. Aroma is fruity, nice Drie fonteinen funk, wet hay, aromas of oxidization are also quite present (sherry, toast, caramel). Taste is sweet, malty, light acidity. Palate is medium bodied, a bit heavier feeling than a typical gueuze, med-light carbonation. Not my favourite but still quite easy drinking, glad I could try this again after a horrible first bottle some years ago.

Bottle (750 ml) @ In de Verzekering tegen de Grote Dorst. Hazy caramel color with a low white head and little lacing. Aroma is of caramelized apples, Drie Fonteinen funk, oxidation, some fruitiness and wood. Taste moderately sweet (not that much for a "Faro) with caramel, funk, oxidation notes that fits quite well in the beer and help balance the sweetness and some fruitiness. Medium body (heavy for a lambic). Moderate carbonation. Moderately dry finish. This is the best Faro I have had for sure, but this is also the less Faro-like that I had. Its surprising how the oxidation fits well in the beer. Tasty and drinkable for an 8% abv Faro.

ivory white head disappears quickly with some lacing. amber colour. aroma funk, sulphur. taste starts of slight sweet, followed by sour and wry aftertaste. very well balanced, never had a faro like this before. medium body and carbonation.  bottle 75 cl / bbf jan-2012

Bottle @ Mikkeller Bar Victoriagade with faroe and Jack, a very nice night out! ..It pours hazy golden with a small bubbling head. Tart, berry, fruits, funky, sour, acid, sweet. liked this a lot! thx!
Hazy amber color. Head disappears quickly. Nice, balanced taste, sour, light malt taste with some sweetness hidden underneath.

Bottle at home. Pours amber with a small off white head. The aroma is leather, sweet malt, citrus and tart berries. The flavor is tart ripe berries, acid, leather and marmalade. Good mix of sweetness and tart fruit. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle 2008 - at sloshfest. Thanks Vincent (BelgBeerGeek). Pours deep amber with a brown hue. Slight to no head. Subtle forest notes, nuts and barnyard funk. Makes one think a lot of the T25, let it be a bit more refined.

Hazy amber color with a small, off white head that left light lacing on the glass. Aroma of brett, bacteria, wood, lemon, and light citrus. Taste is sour, bacterias, lighter fruits, with some sweeter notes before finishing dry.

Pours amber thick and unclear with no head. Aroma is light lambic tart yeast, not much though. Body is full and juicy with a dry ending. Tart flavor is smooth and well balanced without bringing puckering. Some light white grape flavors are really nice.
Brown dredge, no head. Aroma of balsamic vinegar and the stables of an upscale country club. Taste is smooth but sour with hints of brown sugars. Very low carbonation.
Sample at smöf 2013. Sour aroma of wet hay, strangled horse, some tobacco hints. Tiny body with dry and intense sour & vinegar taste. Nice.

Slightly sweet faro based beer. Malty flavour with candy flavour. Drunk from 0.75 cl bottle bought directly from 3 Fonteinen brewery.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

One of my two bottles acquired in belgium this year. I think 2008 vintage? split 2 ways at 60 degrees F. Stored on its side since February (7 months)

A - Its a Faro so I expected a gusher. NOPE. Nice whisp of air. Very hazy ruby red glow. with a 3 finger head that fades slowly to some nice lacing.

S - Fades to some nice lacing. Nose is very funky. Lovely vinous notes with Brett and cherry pie aroma. Hint of sour cherries. 

T - aste is a lot nicer than the nose. Tastes like unblended lambic alright. Slightly more sour than cantillons faro I had on draft. Very sour and the sweetness seems to faded. I get peaches and cherries with a lot of oak. 

M - Sweet and cloyingly so but the oak clearly wins out and its a smooth mouthfeel with a great balance of carbonation 

O - Im looking forward to having this one again. A great beer thats not really seeked out. Its still drinking great!
Did not taste a lot like a faro, thats why I liked it. More like a lambiek with some added malt and spices. Original beer.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2014 Old rating, 0,75l bottle @ home:
Frisk, lett syrlig lukt med preg av malt, eplecidereddik, karamell, litt kirsebær, tørka frukt. Fruktig, lett syrlig smak med preg av malt, tørka frukt, eplecidereddik, karamell, korn, kirsebær. God bitterhet som set litt. Veldig god.

Bottle @ Bruces. I think I bought this through BiaB. The pours deep amber with a small head. The nose is caramelized sugar. Cherry dessert. Earthy mashed plum and dates. Sweet dark fruits. THe taste is more of the same. Caramelized brown sugar. Hints of lemon and woody bugs. Really nice, smooth. Good balance. Not cloying in the slightest. A superior faro indeed. Overall, one of the best faros Ive had. Well played.

Bottle at Jacks farewell at Bruces. Pours a very vibrant but hazy golden colour with a fine beige rind and great lacing. Nose shows toffee, light funk, doughy bread. Taste is all about the heavy funk yet somehow quite balanced between the toffee, bready and fruit driven tones - orange poppiseed cake. Soft driven carbonation with sticky sweetness and a touch of heat. Very sessionable and dry finishing. Good stuff
For what it is its a great beer. Not a favourite style of mine. Still another stable good beer from Armand.

750mL bottle at Grote Dorst, pours a beautiful opaque dark orange amber with a medium off-white head.
Aroma of the traditional  3 Fonteinen Oude Geuze qualities with a subtlety of candied sugar -- with loads of barnyard funk, leather and a hint of candied sugar. Flavour is similar -- probably the least sweet faro Ive had. There are notes of barnyard funk, leather and a subtle use of candied sugar. Very complex and highly drinkable. Delicious stuff, though not in the most elite calibre of 3 Fonteinen beers.

75cl green glass bottle that is gold foiled, caged and corked with a bottled on date of 25/01/2008 and best by date of 01/2012. Im drinking this March 18, 2013 so it has had time to funk right up, hopefully. It pours copper with a slight haze and supporting a light tan colored head of foam. The aroma is a mix of aged cherries and wet old wood with a good dose of earthy moldy basement every now and then. A few more tugs and I get an additional light note of sweet something, malts maybe.  This smells like a slightly soured barleywine, I like it. The taste is woody tart aged cherries that leans into a blunted basement wet plank of wood like sensation. It is smooth and blunted and blended and a little thin on the palate. Nice stuff.

Botella @ Mikkeller Bar with KingCecil and matey Jack. Hazy deep golden, short bubbly head. Lovely tart berry fruity funky sweet like aroma. Good filling mouthfeel indeed. Flavour: fruits and berries and just so lovely tart, sweet like and salty bit like too, lovely acid, dry,

75 cl bottle.
Originally rated on 20101126.
Pours murky amber color with a medium head. Aroma of sweet and ripe fruits, citrus fruits also, some yeast and spices. Flavor of lots of fruits, some berry notes, yeast and spices. Surprisingly sour for a faro. Excellent.

Bottle 2008 vintage. Thanks a bunch Theis. Pours  murky brownish red. Minimal head. You get a lot of grain, sour dough, rye bread notes, herbal  and spicy notes,  lacto, vinegar notes, green apples.  A bit oxidised. Taste is like sultana raisin juice with hits of dry lemon and loads of lacto. Dried fruits, and apple cider vinegar. Really nice!
Poured from a 750ml bottle. A very balanced sour. Notes of peach, cherry, sweet, lactose, sour apple, malty. This is very easy to drink.

This was a treat, nice to finally see the top of the faro ladder! .. . pours a murky tan .. medium foam .. . trodden prune, clumpy sugar, barn bucket, and rope funk .. . slick mouth .. . pretty tasty . . .. Well, I could be wrong, but I believe, uh, diversity is an old, old wooden ship that was used during the civil war era.

2009 bottle. Not much in the appearance and hardly any carbonation. The scent is a tad funky. I picked up on a nice fruit scent. There is primarily sour grapes in the flavor. Overall a fine drink for its style. The palate isnt hit hard and the tartiness fades nicely.
Very sessionable gueze due to the big caramel flavour. Very strange, even for a belgian lambic. Thanks Jack for a good couple of hours on the verandah.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2013 Bottle: Vintage 2008:
Pours an almost headless (just some bubbles on top), quite flat, hazy amber orange colored beer.
Smell wild yeast, brett, wood, hint of molasses, berries, wood, brown sugars.
Taste is tart with yeast, sugars, honey, chalk, wood, caramel, sugars, barleys, sour yeasty herbs and darker herbs.
Aftertaste is light wild yeasty and tart with some brown sugars, barleys, caramel and wood.
Low to no carbo, soft light watery mouthfeel, medium to fuller body and a light watery texture.
Another great beer, delicious, balanced and easy drinkable!
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text:
750ml bottle shared by Dallas 
Appearance: Clear golden with a small off-white head and good lacing 
Aroma: Tart fruit, caramel, woody and cherries 
Taste: Tart cherries, caramel and woody 
Very nice and easy drinking.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2013 Orange-light brown. hazy, off white head. Aroma of bread crusts, a little toffee, brown sugar, moderate sourness and acidity. Flavor: moderate acidity, rustic earthy character, bread crusts, tannic berry note, a little toffee and burnt sugar, some leathery age. Very complex and well balanced. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

[4731-20120818] Bottle. Toasted candied jam yeast aroma. Slightly hazy, orange amber body with no lasting head. Sour light raspberry stem fruit flavour has a nice simple finish. Medium body. Wow, great sour up front followed through with a balanced finish. (8/3/7/4/15) 3.7
(@ Campground Brewdown 2012, Millmont, PA)
Syrlig geuze karaktär med smak av blöt ylle, halm, hö, äpple, jäst, plommon, vinbär. Torr och en aning för söt men en trevlig smakupplevelse.

Flaska från Brill. Typisk orangebrun dimmig vätska. Doft likt en geuze med stall, fuktigt trä och syrliga äpplen men ändå sötare med drag av plommonsylt. Perfekt balans mellan syra och sötma. Inget tar över, lätta plommondrag med liten kärnbeska, stall, hästfilt och sötsyrliga äpplen. Riktigt riktigt god.

very happy to have found this one ! 
onley had one faro so far (being the lindemans) wich chocked me on how much i like it !  3 fonteinen is my favourite sour by far, so those 2 combining? hell yeah ! and the pure luck to find this , even lifts my happiness and high expectations up !

opens very agresively ! twisting the metal cap makes the cork pop itself out already ! no gusher, though ( luck stikes again !) 

pours blonde-orange, imidiatly fading foam. great how insanely much smell this has ! definetly more sourness than the lindemans ( yeah i know, what a shock )

taste : waaw very sour ! that means, for a faro. kinda uncomparable with the other one i had ! this apple taste as i can onley desribe it ( aplle with the sourness of it) comes in the swallowing and first aftertase, followed by that .. typical 3 fonteinen-ish taste, and other apple taste. 
this drinks inb layers and is definetly very very nice ass well ! if this were available like lagers, id drink faro lake a lagerboy drinks lager , if they keep tasting this nice !  glad i didnt share the bottle :p

Bottle at ÖÖWF cons 2012-11-17 Göteborg
AR: sour, tart, white wine, white grapes, wee spicey 
AP: clear copper, no head
F: tart, grape fruit bitterness, wee grainy, semi sweet, citric

75 cl. fles gedeeld met  Sebletitje tijdens de Belgian Ratebeer Winter Gathering of Ultimate Evil. Gekocht tijdens de opendeurdagen bij de brouwerij. Dit is veel ouder dan ik initieel gedacht had, gebotteld op 25/01/2008 dus dit is al 4 bijna 5 jaar oud, nog leuker dit is houdbaar tot 01/2012 dus dit is eigenlijk al vervallen :) Dit smaakt eigenlijk als 4 jaar oude gebottelde 3F Faro (wat eigenlijk best wel heel indrukwekend is). Ik ben dol op hun Faro, enige echt  fenomenale faro een van de hel, heel weinige goede faros wat nog altijd niet echt een stijl is wat mij betreft :) Donker extreem wazig amber met weinig in de weg van witte kraag. Geur is een iets lichtere zoetheid, zoete boerderijen, hooi, bruine en kandijsuiker, lichte funk. Dit heeft dezelfde prachtige zoetheid als de vat versie, bijna een oude hop toets, zoete boerderijen, hooi, bruiden en kandijsuiker, overjaars fruiit, zoete sinaasappelschil, karamel, toffee, lichte aarde, Vol, zeker voor de stijl maar minder vol dan de vat versie, mogelijk de leeftijd, iets minder gas dan gewoonlijk. Lekker, ik ben niet helemaal gekant tegen het feit dat hij overweeg om dit nog eens te maken :)
Bottle at ÖÖWF 2012, vintage 2008. Nose: overly mature citrus, murky, basement. Tastes of dark citrus, mature. tangy and refreshing.

Bottle. First pour is a beautiful crystal clear slightly pinkish tinged amber body with a small fizzy off-white head that faded to a thin ring and thin covering. The nose is a really wonderful mix of funky Gueuze and slightly sweet sugar. Not quite as funky as the Cantillon or regular Drie Fonteinen Faro. Seem cleaner and brighter somehow, quite a contradiction for a Lambic really.  The flavor has quite a nice balance to it as well, funky cellar and traditional Lambic up front but then a good bit of sweetness towards the back end. Theres a nice almost citrusy quality on the finish, reminds me a bit of a nice tart glass of fresh lemonade for a second. This is easily the finest bottled Faro that Ive had, but not quite as rustic and raw as the Cantillon and regular Drie Fontenein. The mouthfeel differs quite a bit as well, with this being much sharper and with much more lively carbonation. On the whole though, this is about as authentic as you can get while being able to enjoy it at home and from a bottle.

Sampled at SBWF11
Hazy copper with a white head.
Sourish but still with sweet notes from brown sugar.
this is good for its style but the style it self is not one of my favorites. its too sweet, tastes of overripe apples
Sample @ SBWF 12. Amber colour with an off-white head. Aroma is acidic, sour, sugar. Flavour is also acidic, sour, but with some sweetness to it.

Peaches, malts, funk. Really intensive aroma. Body is a bit sour, not overpowering so though. Really nice balance in this one.

15cl sample @ SBWF12. Poured red amber with almost no head. Aroma has barnyard, sour berries, but also some mild sweet notes from dried fruits I mostly find in barley wines. Extraordinary aroma overall. Flavor is tart and acidic, vinegar, but also rye, raisins and yeast. One of the best in this style I have tried. Complex, very easy to drink.
Hazy golden with a small white head - sour malt aroma - sour malty taste with hints of sweetness - lingering sour end, not as sweet as expected but still very good

Bottle. Creamy white good mostly deminishing head. Amber colour. Light malty and hoppy medium sour aroma. Light sweet and moderate sour flavor. More sour than other Faros but still nice. Long finish. Creamy palate.
light sour fruit aroma,amber, hazy, off white foam, lightly sour, light body, fizzy, nice sour finish.

Amber coloured and hazy. Has an off-white head, medium duration. Aroma of barnyard, acid, faint sugars, yeasty (bret.). Flavor is heavy acidic, light sweetness too. Light astringent. Dry, acidic texture and soft carbonation.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste brett, caramel, malt, notes of fruit and hops. Nice and sour finish.

2012-08-18. Dark orange amber body, headless. 3+ Mild aroma, light funk, need to tease it out a bit but it is pleasant. Flavour is pretty sour, acidic, sort of lemony with a light funk. 7+ Average bodied palate. 3+ Enjoyable. A very solid sour. Bottle, Campground Brewdown 2012 shared by MaxxDaddy

750ml bottle from brewolf. Thanks. Pours a cloudy amber color with a small white head that immediately fizzes away to a fine ring. The aroma is distinctly funky with sweat, horseblanket and a bit of rotting fruit. The flavor is sour with green apples, melons, soured mangoes, acidic wines and salt&pepper. The palate is full and silky smooth with lively carbonation. Finishes long, dry and sour. Overall: So this is a faro eh, nothing like the Chapeau that had a few years ago. I loved this, great stuff.

Bottle courtesy of Max at Kramers Campground Brewdown 2012. Pours a deep hazy amber body with thin carbonated white lacing. Aroma is light funk, sweet malty fruit and earthy musk. Mouthfeel is soft with notes of soft, tart fruit, light musk, dust, dirt, funk, and a nice acidity.

Thanks to MaxxDaddy on RB for bringing this bottle to Campground Brewdown. Yet another Drie Fonteinen off the list.

A - Pours murky brown with a small one finger tall off-white head leaving very small trails of lace down parts of the glass.

S - Smells of very light funk, dark candied sugar, dark fruits, oak, caramel and a light mineral quality. This one isnt as funky as I was expecting.

T - Starts off with some sweet caramel malt and plenty of dark candied sugar that never really go away. Hints of dark fruits, oak, light musty funk and some minerals help to break up the sweetness. Finish is pretty dry, lingering on the palate long after the finish.

M - Medium body with moderate carbonation. Kinda sweet with some lingering dryness.

O - I enjoyed this one for what it is. It definitely sports some interesting flavors but it really isnt my style. Fun to try but I wouldnt actively seek it out.

The beer is dark yellow and slightly hazy, with a small head that leaves virtually no lacing behind. The aroma brings sugar, with a mild funk. That being said, this is the best faro I have yet had, though my experience in this genre is quite limited. The beer is lightly sweet, and still brings a helping of funk, albeit muted by the sugary presence. A decent beer and a fun experience, I would have this again.

750ml bottle, packaged 01/24/08, best by 01/12, consumed 01/11.  Wow, this stuff is different.  Ive really never had anything like it.  The pour yields a very lightly hazy, dark honey colored body.  A small beige film is conjured up, separating to a thin, lasting ring.  Skinny, delicate flares and trailing micro spot lace dot the glass.  The nose is truly distinct, drawing from the lambic component to show notes of apricot, tart, buggy wood, pithy orange and lemon acidity.  Brett is distinct, and there is a farmy horseblanket funk to it.   Where it gets odd (not necessarily in a bad way, just in a different way) is in the baseline notes of fermented out rock candy and mild cola malt, as well as in the hint of white grape skin.  Somehow, the combo works for me.  Its not like any faro Ive ever had, and as I understand it, thats not exactly what it is anyway.  Flavors are a bit more funky and sour, touching on apricot, tart lemon, grapefruit, and tangerine, also showing wet, soured wood and dry, buggy brett.  The residual candy sugar background note is less prominent, but it still plays a major contributing role.  The palate sports a tingly, lively, drying carbonation up front, showing just a bit of dried out residual sugars on the back end.  Overall, this is quite an interesting brew.  I didnt quite know what to make of it at first, but its 3F lambic roots show big enough, especially in the flavor, to keep this sourhead happy.  Great brew.

Taste : Quite acidic and lactic. Great tartness with a lingering sweetness on the finish. Great citrusy notes. 

Overall : Nice funk and nice tartness. The sugar presence is really enjoyable. The sweetness that it provides is very faint. However, I thought it was more sour and more acidic than what Im used too with 3 Fonteinen. Still it was quite complex with nice funk. Interesting take on the style. Very different. Im really curious to see how this one ages.

Mild säuerlicher Geruch mit dumpfen Himbeernoten, auch Andeutungen von Trauben scheinen vorhanden. Mild säuerliches, sich ausbreitendes Aroma im Antrunk, etwas holzig, die Säuerlichkeit wird intensiver. Aromen von Grapefruit, in das sich ein herber Ton gut einfügen kann. Zum Ende hin wird das Bier recht trocken, was sich hier aber noch in Grenzen hält. Noch wenig vollmundig, leicht bitter-trocken, der Grapefruit-Ton kommt erneut hervor. Süffig, im Abgang etwas scharf, was hier einen Störton darstellt. Ansonsten rund aber im Nachgeschmack zu trocken, was sich in Teilen auch auf den hier weiter vorhandenen Grapefruit-Ton zurückführen lässt. /11/11/9//11


Mild säuerlicher Antrunk mit geringfügig fruchtigen und stärker holzigen Beinoten. Vollmundig, die Säuerlichkeit passt in ihrer Intensität gut zu den starken Holznoten. Das Bier bleibt auf einer Intensitätsstufe, dunkelmalzig, harmonisch, einfach rund. Später ein wenig trocken, getreidig. Leicht grasig, wenig süß. Gut! 10/11/13/12/12/12

January 08 bottling date. Monstrous thanks to sflpunk for this one. Cloudy teak colored pour with a very small bubbly head on the edges. Aroma holds awesome leathery funk, along with hay and lemon but on a darker lemon than, say, a gueuze. Also some phenomenal fruity tones, including orange marmalade and apricot jam. Flavor is impressively sour, with more huge barnyard presence that meshes with those fruity preserve notes closer to the end of the flavor. Added undertones of sweet cherry, candied sugar, and minerality contribute to a sensational complexity overall. Palate is wonderfully sour and sweet, with the perfection carbonatoin that is present but not sharp at the start and melts away later, yielding to the tartness. Absolutely awesome.

750ml bottle @ Pikkulintu, Helsinki

Pours brownish red with a minimal head. Aroma has hints of spices, pepper  and sourness. Taste is quite sour with a sticky and sweet finish. Notes of caramel, sugar and cola. Well balanced.
Pours brown with a thin off white head.  Smells funky with some residual sugary hints and fruity undertones.  Tastes lactic with some acidic dry elements.  Some grassy hints emerge as the beer warms.

Rating #1400! Bottle pour thank rciesla for sharing. Brown pour with tan head. Aroma is very similar to other 3F lambics, acetic like aroma, mouthwatering. Flavor varies with a bit more of nutty malt and light spice tones, accompanying the tart flavor of this lambic. Not as sweet as other faros.

750ml bottle thanks to bu11zeye.
Medium amber pour with almost no head.  Lemon, tart, and funky aromas - flavors of citrus, slightly bitter, sour, and lactic.
Shared bottle courtesy of tarjei. Clear, orange with a white film. Wood, oak, pickled berries and fruits in the aromas. Fresh and bitter flavors with a malty finish. Medium body. Rich carbonation.

Thanks peter.  Excited to try this!   Solid beer.   Pleasant earthy, light funk, cherry pit fruit, and a touch of balsamic.   Moderate sourness with some pleasant Cherry apple fruit and spice character.  Great.
Bottle. Amber/brown with small off-white head. Flavour is sour, fruit, tart, little barnyard, little acid, little sweet and citrus.
This is a beer what remind me on the first Tuverbol off Brouwerij Lottebol, maybe a copy !!!!  To mutch alchol in the back, bud a good sourness .

750 ml bottle via trade with michael-pollack- thanks again, Pollack! Pours a murky golden-orange with lots of visible sediment and a small white head. Aroma of apples, balsamic, lemon citrus, oaky funk, grapes, and a little lactic acid. Flavor of balsamic vinegar, tart lemon juice, grape skins, oaky funk, and some dried herbs and spices. Medium-bodied, with an acidic, tart mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. Faro is not a style I know much about but I really enjoyed this.

DLD 11.  Bottle thanks to phaleslu! Pours hazy orange with thin white head, aroma has notes of vinegar, apple, some tart lemon and some funk.  Taste is nice and smooth, some acetic sour going into lemon, tart apple, some other grape notes with a touch of funk, and a slightly sweet finish.

Consumed at a recent DC area tasting. Served in a SAVOR snifter. Thanks to GT for opening this.

Pours a moderate golden-yellow color with a good white head and some mild lacing as it goes down. The nose contains a good amount of breadiness as well as some yeast and spice. Light sugary character along with a moderate amount of Brett funk. Its profile is pretty similar to 3F Oude Gueuze, but a bit subdued. Flavor is nice with a bit of apple and barnyard funk. Theres is a touch more sweetness than a normal wild, though its really more noticeable in the mouthfeel, where a mild sugary sweetness coats my palate. Good carbonation. Overall, quite a solid effort and something I thoroughly enjoyed.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-30-2011

To celebrate my 7100th Rating. Thanks to Anker for hooking me up with this. 75cl Bottle. Pours murky unclear orange with a creamy and stable white head and lacings. Nose is cellar, horseblanket and oak. Flavor is dominated by oak and vanilla with a touch of brown sugar and some acidic notes. Crisp and dry and quite interesting. However this will not be a 3 Fonteinen favourite.

murky tan pour, light white ring. Rindy, celery note, sugar cane nose, bit of tempered hay and funk. Flavor is thin, undercarbonated, heavy sugar with light rind, hay, and grapefruit. The sugar keeps it softer and kills off light funk.

Bottle thanks to ditmier. Pours out a hazy brown with some red highlights topped with a small head. Aroma was of funk, lemon zest, oak, earth tones, and some apple. Taste was much as the aroma with some nice funk, barnyard, and fruit going on.

750ml bottle pours a hazy, light brown with a clumpy, white head.  Nose is sour, lots of brett, band aid, lemons, tart, zesty citrus.  Flavor is acidic, sweet, candy sugar, balsamic vinegar, lemon pulp, grass, grapefruit.  Very tart, full bodied finish.

75cl bottle at home vintage 2008. Was not sure what to expect from this but overall it wasnt my sort of lambic. The aroma was of horse blanket and caramel infused with a sour lambic. The flavour was the same but it was not very balanced or enjoyable. There was a very strong burnt sugar note which did not mix well with an authentic lambic base. Nice experiment but its not for me. However I would love to try it again in 10 years just to see what happens to it!

Bottle, Huge thanks to ericandersnavy. Pours a hazy, dark amber with fizzy beige head. Aroma is very acidic, musty and farmhouse. Flavor is exactly the same and extremely tart. Mouthfeel is light-medium body with fizzy carb. Overall, damn good brew! Very enjoyable.

750ml that I got at Drie in Beersel, poured into my 3 tulip...A dark orange cloudy beer, very unusual for a lambic. Light tope head, good retention with a thick but small cap and great thick lacing...The aroma is really nice and balanced, lots of oak with medium horse blanket, not as strong as expected...At first the taste is malty and bread, but then comes a huge burst of sour horse blanket. Horse blanket settles down as your drink, medium strength lends to drinkability. Additional notes of oak and candied sugar. I really like it...The feel is ok, not the typical pucker, attack of the senses. 

Overall, a really good lambic, probably the best unblended Ive had. Really malty which is a nice twist, worth getting for sure.

75cl bottle, thanks travlr.  Small white head atop cloudy amber body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, sour, funk/horse blanket.  Taste is medium sweet, horse blanket, some funk, light sourness.  Light-medium body, some acidity.  Much more sour than I expect for a Faro.

Bottle shared by Travlr.  Pours cloudy yellow with a small, fizzy white head, short retention with light lacing.  Aroma and flavor are acetic acid, grapes, horse blanket, spicy hops, meal, and cereal.  Medium-light body, light warmth, medium carbonation with a dry finish.  This is not as sweet as other Faros.

Bottle, thx Travlr. Pours hazy brown with a small fizzy head. Very funky aroma, lots of lemon, brett, fruits, oak. Taste is strongly sour, but not off-putting, lots of citrus, fizzy fruit juice. Good stuff.

from erzbierschof.ch - hazy reddish-amber colour with a poor head retention; complex and fair aroma of wood, cheese, vinegar and red fruits; full-bodied and moderately carbonated, very tasty, sweet and fairly sour; woody and cheesy finish with more notes of vinegar and apples - superb!
Opaque orange-brown pour with a thin tan head.  Funky woody aroma with lots of oeak.  Flavor is earthy with lemon, citrus, and sweet apple cider notes.  Very tart and sour.

750mL thanks to Travlr. The pour is a cloudy amber with white bubbles coming up. Doesnt really look like faro. Aroma is very funky and sour, intense full geuze notes coming on: sour fruits, lemon, grapefruit, sweat, moderate Brett/barnyard. Taste is full geuze just straight up: heavy lactic, fresh citrus, light tannic white grape skins, lemon, funky sweat and white vinegar. Full on sour, zippy palate. A nice surprise although not like a faro in the normal sense. Could just as well be unblended lambic in my book. Yum!

75cl bottle. Shared with good friends. Hazy orange colour with a non-existant head. Aroma is, not suprisingly sour. Lots of yeast and carbonation. Some vegetables and also brown candy sugar. Flavour is also sour. Lots of citrus and bret yeast. Short aftertaste. Still not into lambic.
Sweet and sour nose with light acetic acid, some cotton candy, hay and horseblanket. Taste is moderately sweet, moderately sour, lots of cider vinegar, some honey, light lemon and funk.

Bottle. Pours a hazy orange color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity and slightly sweetish tart funky aroma. Fruity sour tart funky flavor with some weak hints of caramel. Has a fruity sour tart funky finish.

Bottle. Clear, simple amber, small white head. Aroma is very pure with a strong sourness. Somo rural components, but it has some nice caramel and sugar notes as well. Strong citrus. Taste is highly sour with many fruity notes, oak, sour berries and vinegar. Some caramel sweetness before you are slaughtered by sourness . Lovely. Lots of earth. Lovely.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2013 January 2008 Bottling.

A: Orangish-red bpdy. Very thin off-white head. A nice thin skim remains on top as soapy lacing is left behind.

S: Alternating blasts of oak and tart berry-like aromas. Some lactic funk and lemon runs underneath. Some nice sweaty aromas as well.

T: Similar to the nose as a nice blend of wood, funk, sourness, tartness, sweat, and some berry. A bit unusual, but quite nice.

M: Silky smooth body. I think more carbonation would have been a nice addition. The sourness/tartness is a bit timid, but is still quite noticeable.

O: A very nice, refreshing lambic. Interesting and unique. Will have to track down more bottles soon

My Bottom Line:
Dusty funk dominates this simple Lambic until a lemony undercurrent washes the tongue with sustained tartness. 

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A veil of foam surfs the murky dark amber.
-Alcohol is a no-show in the flavor profile.
-The docile effervescence increased drinkability.
-This was not nearly as complex as most Drie Fonteinen offerings, but it is still an interesting creation the likes of which we rarely get to taste on this side of the beer world.

Bottle.

Bouteille verte de 750 ml, avec bouchon de liège, partagée lors dune dégustation Ratebeer Montréal. Arôme: Odeur de brett et de citron. Apparence: La couleur est orangée-ambrée voilée. Présence dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût dagrumes sucrés avec une pointe de caramel et de vinaigre. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement vineuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de pommes vertes en arrière goût. (Rating #3568)

Bouteille de 750 ml, lors dune dégustation. Merci beaucoup Martin ! Arômes très funky de brettanomyces (foin sec), beaucoup de fruits jaunes (pêches, citron) et légère touche boisée. Robe orangée et trouble, peu de mousse et effervescence moyenne. Relativement corpulente pour une bière de fermentation spontanée, la bière est très fruitée (citron,pamplemousse) et rustique. Lalcool est très bien dissimulé. Finale légèrement lactique et très citrique (on a vraiment limpression de mordre dans un citron). Original et très intéressant !

[3/8/11] Bottle at a friends house in Amsterdam. Hazy amber with a medium, quickly-dissipating, white head. Aroma of brett, some wood, citrus and light caramel notes. Sour flavor with a bit of sweeter hints, some lemon and a sharp bone-dry finish with some alcohol and some bitterness. Medium-bodied. Good but not great as other beers from 3 Fonteinen. I dont know if it originally was intended to be one, but this is definitely not a Faro now.

Bottle, shared with Palme. Pours a murky, deep orange (bordering on brown) body with a small white head. Nice. Aroma is subtle and complex: candy sugar, brett notes, barnyard funk, dried fruits, almonds and some nutty, woody notes. Taste is matching: smooth brett tones, sweet malts, candy sugar, hay, yellow apples wood and hints of burnt plastic (in a nice way, believe it or not...tis The Way of the Lambic...) and bakers yeast. The added candy sugar makes this a sort of crossbreed between a Belgian ale and a classic lambic. Which I do like. A really, really nice brew and a truly original lambic.

my first faro!
light tan, faintly hazy, no bubbles.
this is great! smells like gueze.
med body and almost no carbonation
a gueze with a faint sugary character. i love this!

0.75l bottle shared with ClubGonzo. Pours a murky as hell deep orange body with lots of big black sediments and a quite decent white fading head. Nose is vinegar, slightly fruity and some faint raisin hints along with the wild yeast and orange peel. Good carbonation, and medium bodied. Tastes quite nice. There is a distinct sweetness from the malts, almost candy sugar sweetness, green apple and wool along with some hints of pear. The wild yeast really sticks out. Lightly tart. Finishes off in a dry, woody and slightly sour longlasting finish. Nicely balanced and quite good.
Hazy amber with a small, disappearing head. Sour and funky aroma with a kind taste that is a bit caramelly sweet and just a little sour and funky. Very nice drinkability
Nice, tart caramel and candied orange aroma.  Flavor is dusty, sour caramel.  Medium acidity, but richer and maltier than most lambics I have had - not cloying either.

Pours amber with a white head. Aroma is course filled with spontaneous yeasts with leather and horse blanket, but also caramel and nuts, very faint chocolate, vinegar, sweet berries. Taste also has a clear impression of spontaneous fermentation, brett, lacto, oak, some vinegar, hints of caramel and nuts along with cherries. Vert tart, very good. Nice carbonation. 2-27-11

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2014 Pours amber/orange with a white head. Wild yeast on the nose with lemon peel, sour berries and some caramel sweetness in the background. Taste of vinegear, sour berries, a little bit bread and some caramel sweetness in the background here also.

Poured for me by Armand in a sampler glass while talking about his brewery. Nice guy, who makes great beer. Visit his place if you are ever around Brussels, or make a trip just to go there. Its worth it. But bring enough money, we walked out spending way more than we thought we would. 
Pours a golden straw with a hefty sized white head. The head stuck around the whole time. Which really wasnt long as I had the small ~6 oz. glass down in about a minute. 
Great lambic scent of grass, funk, wheat and sourness. 
Not as sour as some of his other beers, but balanced well with the sweetness it offers. Same smells came back as taste, especially the wheat and sourness. Great balance of everything, but the wheat, sourness, and sweetness really shine. 
Carbonation mellows out any strong alcohol you expect to be there with an 8 abv on the label. That and it is just so well balance by the slight sweetness you get and the sour feeling you get typical of a lambic. 
Very drinkable despite the high abv. I had to constantly turn down samplers due to my 2 hour drive home. But if I had the time I definitely would have stuck around to drink more. Good thing I got a few bottles to drink at the house. 

If you can get your hands on this gem, dont turn it down. And perhaps age a bit if you can wait. Excellent beer, excellent brewery, and an excellent brewer.

Bottle bought at Drie Fonteinen Open Day. Pours a nicely brown/amber color with good lacing.The nose is moderately funky, some sweet candi sugar and caramel, barnyard, bread and wood. 
Taste: what a nice surprise. Not overpoweringly acidic, with a great balanced sweetness. Fruity sugars are present, the alcohol is extremely well hidden and the aftertaste is long and sour again. A very successful beer experiment. I think this one has great aging potential! Happy to know I still have some for later. Great beer!!

750 ml bottle. Hazy dark amber. Medium-sized fine-laced white head. Earthy and wooded aromas with a hint of acidity. Dry, a little puckering, sourness at first. Some tannins. Delicate apricoty and minty flavours. Some hop bitterness. Lively fine carbonation. Very refreshing beer with some sweetness in the background. A great beer with nice complexity.

Funky, fruity, slow carbonation. Pleasant rhubarb sourness, not enamel-removing acid. Vinous, hard and sour apples, pucky dry finish. But there is an unmistakable labic character -there is no trace of the grain or malt at all.

Bottle.
Pours clear dark amber with a slight yeasty haze. A small, creamy film head. Aroma is tart, oaky, caramel and toffee, good funky barnyard and some Belgian sugar. Light carbonation, fine dry and creamy mouthfeel. Wonderfully balanced flavour, light caramel and Belgian sugar as base with lovley oaky dryness, mild viniousness, fair tartness and a bretty touch on top. Mild sharpness to it. Very delicious.

Bottled. Pours hazy amber/orange with a small tanned head. Aroma is acidic fruits, vinegar and some vineous charachter. Taste is dry fruity, red ripe fruits and strong acidic without overdoing it, nice balanced towards the malty body. Very refreshing and easy drinkable. Nice and interesting.

Thanks to bu11zeye for sharing this bottle. Glad to try another Faro. 

The beer pours an orange-amber color with a white head. The aroma is heavy on the lemons, apples and caramel malt. There is a good bit of tartness to the aroma and a little bit of funk. 

The flavor is similar, but a little bitter in my opinion. I get light to medium farmhouse funk. as well as some sour apples and lemons. There is also a little bit sugar mixed in, but the beer is still a lot more sour than the other Faros that I have tried.

Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A very good beer. Drie Fonteinen never disappoints.

Bottle with a best before of (if I can read the number correctly) 04/2012. Pours with a hazed golden body and a fading white head. Aroma is funky, cotton candy, brown sugar, cork and musty. Flavor is sweet and vinous, with funky notes and some acid. Lively bubbles and good acidity. Tasty.
bottle, provided by bu11zeye,  cloudy orange with a peppery funk nose, flavors of sour citrus fruits, cottony, mineral,  very nice

(750ml bottle)  Pours a cloudy orange body with a small white head.  Aroma of fresh filleted fish (in a good way), lemon, horseblanket, berries, light yogurt, and wood.  Flavor of lemon, grapefruit, subtle candi sugar, lacto, grass, and brett with a dry wood finish.

Shared by Jonas...is a rusty dark orange, hazy color with lasting head. Aroma is very faro, sweet, fruity with lots of crushed apples. Soft juicy palate is a marriage of faro and lambic due to the acidic finish. Has a nice amt of carbonation. Is much tarter, more acidic than it smells, with lovely nuances and complexity. There is wood but not too much, fruit but not too much sweetness. Persimmon and mild ripe Bosc pear. Orange peel candy. Excellent body. More please!

Medium offwhite head. Hazy amber body. Waxy floral horseblanket aroma with grapefruit, cheese and metal notes. Harmonic and balanced. Sour-sweetish grapefruit and horseblanket taste with waxy floral notes. Mid-bodied. Sharp, biting mouthfeel. Dry-sour floral herbal grapefruit aftertaste with metallic wooden yoghurt notes. A little honey, too. Extremely complex. There are a million things going on here. Fairly harsh acidic edge. A sipper. (0.75l bottle, wine monopoly Vika, Oslo.)

Bottled at Pressklubben, Stockholm.  Hazy amber, minimal head. Juicy concentrated aroma of horseblanket, vinegar and raisins. Acidic with a slight sweetish overlay. Soft and rounded with lots of juicy citrus. Above medium bodied with a slight, mild alcohol warmth. The richness and complexity is put even more on open display by the slighy sweetness and warmth. The downside is that is a bigger, slightly less drinkable beer, indeed more suitable for winter temperatures.

This is a wow bottle!
Such a nice palet, a relative strong beer.

like the 0,75l bottle anyway, you can put this one between X-mas beers!
A wintergeuze with floral, alcohol, woody, and of course sourish accent

A hazy dirty dark lambic with a thin white head. In aroma, a superb lactic acid with epsom salts, horseblanket, so classic, turned to 11. In mouth, a nice smooth sourish malt, light vinegar, refreshing and smooth, I really enjoyed this one. Shared with Orlando crew, Jan 6 2011.

750 cc bottle from a Belgian Christmas Elf.  Pours turbid ruddy Carolina mud/clay color with minimal off-white head.  Nose is sour mashy gueuezy fruit, yeasty, lactic.  Tastes tart, rich, complex as hell, very fruity, with a lot of lactic acidity.  Smooths out as it warms, retaining the cobwebby dank ester quality.  Very nice.

Rating #1111 -- two elevens are better than one!  Bottle from my secret santa -- many thanks for this rarity!!  Pour a reddish/orange hue with a lasting off-white head.  Smells predominantly of vinegar and dried orange peel.  Tastes of each with added notes of sweet malt and candied peaches.  Harmonious and delicious.

Bottle This beer rocks! Murky amber ale with a small, creamy, white head. The aroma is funky and sweet and lends a strong component of toasted oak flanked by a minor note of bourbon.  Medium to full-bodied with a milky mouthfeel and stinging carbonation. The flavor is not all that similar to the nose  funky, fruity and pretty darned sour. Sweetness is low. Finishes tart, astringent and bone-dry. This bottle of world class beer was very generously shared by Beerlando!
bottle at home ... amber ... no head ... sharp light sour ... light funk nose ... sharp sourness ... little vinegar ... light lemon ... not really me
Bottle shared at Mikeys tasting. Pours cloudy peach. Nose and taste of tart fruit, candi sugar, yeast and old wood. Mouthfeel is full. Very well-balanced.
Hazy amber red color with a ring of head.  Aroma of sour apples, tart cherries, yeast and vinegar.  Nice tart flavor with vineous fruit notes.  Now packaged with a crab in every bottle!
Deep red/orange pour. Aroma of vinegar, cherries, cheese, dusty yeast, sour apples. Flavor has such a great tartness, acetic acid, oak, tart cherries, light red wine. Very delicious.

750 ml Bottle.  Pours a slightly hazed woody amber red with no head- although some slight very soft carbonation at first, then it seems mostly still.  Aroma is funky lambic like brett and sourness, cherry pit, mineral, cherry pie, rustic woody, earthy with dirt, light horse, kind of a cross between flemish red and lambic.  Flavor is earthy mineral, lambic upfront, lacto sourness, slight citrus, medium citrusy funk, lemon, then turns to cherry pit, light vinegar, woody, burnt caramelized (well fermented out) malts, fully fermented caramelized candy sugar, and a big sour finish which seemed a nice blend and mix of different tart acids- lactic, tartaric and acetic (though none are too sharp).  Mid-palate trace of sweetness, but it is mostly just a good sour beer wihtout any real evidence candy sugar was ever added either in brewing, fermentation or afterwards which leads me to say this is unlike any other Faro ever since it is not sweet at all.  Wihtout knowing how this was made myself, I have to tell myself this is leaning mostly towards what a great Flemish red is like, maybe mixed in with a strong lambic for some added funk and lactic acidity.  Faro?  no.  I still really liked this beer- nothing offensive, and just a whole lot better than I expected (thinking it would be sweet- which it wasnt at all).  Great experiment whatever it is!

0,75L corked bottle. Shimmering orange colored body, with a carpet of beige bubbles on top. Layers of aromas; Mild fruity acidity, port, wooden tones, faint vinegar and sourcream. Notes of mould and cellar. Taste is mostely fruity acidic and sour, but  well rounded by a perfect amount of residual sugars from the malts. Nice vinous with tones of wood, spices and soft toasted malts. Suggestions of farmyard and cellar. Strong body. Smooth in the mouth. An utterly complex and perfctly balanced beer. Im amazed, by far the best I have had in this genre.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2012 Opened on 12.31.2010 to usher in 2011. Opens with a pop.

Brick red with a barely off-white, pinkish head. One and a half finger head. 

Lots of vinegar and funk in the nose. I pick up on young strawberries, vanilla, and lots of soft oak character. Taste is an interesting interplay between sweet, sour, and musty funk. The berry notes are reminiscent of dried lingonberries which combines with the wet woodiness and (lots of) cheese rind; finishes tannic, but with notes of sweet honey from the addition of sugar. Surprisingly malty and sweet, with notes of vanilla.

Lightly funky, lightly tart, with a nice sourness. A great beer.

Brownish orange pour with a vivacious offwhite head. The aroma holds huge funk, must, and acidity, all balanced in the perfect proportions. The flavor is quintessential 3 Fonteinen balance with some puckering sweetness. Very low residual sugar levels. Ultra dry crisp palate with only the slightest lingering sweetness. Truely amazing.

bottle from Bierkompass. Hazy amber-orange colour, small head. Sour nose. Dry palate, rather tart, slightly acid and vinegar-like, balanced with some shy sweetness and a spicy touch. A very interesting beer.

Bottle from Raf at Borefts 2010.  Some warm toffee.  Sweetish.  Love the aroma.  Though sweetish.  Just stunning.  Balanced by sourness.  Verging on the salt n vinegar but perfect mix of sweet and sour.  Beautiful soft and the toffee is gorgeous.

Bottle - Chris Os PRE-NY tastings - thanks to honoury UK crew Jackie and Simon whom really should get themselvees on this site. 

I also want to make a special mention to Raf whom has personally given me a bottle at Borefts which I am waiting to open on a special ocasion. 

Acid levels; tart, peaches, wild funky shit and barnyard. Taste is tart; peaches, nice acidicy levels, great balance, stunning drinkability and oh so clean. Gorgeous drink and a a pure ten on taste and aroma. 3 Fonteinen I love and cant get enough of. This is a classic and superb winter lambic. Amazing.

(Bottle, thanks mybestfriend) Pours hazy dark orange to amber with pale sand coloured head. The aroma is surprisingly bretty and lactic with horse blanket, mould, citrus, elder and barnyard. The malt brings straw and crackers. There is less brett c fruitiness than in your regular 3F. Also tiny sugary. The flavour is dry and medium to heavily acidic. Almost no bitterness. Citrus, funky brett and dry malt alongside a light sugary sting. The mouthfeel is tart and light carbonated. Acidic, burning brett in the finish. Medium bodied.

750ml bottle (BierKompass.de) - shared by mto - many thanks!
8 Lovely aged woody butter and resin aroma, smothered with bretty sourness, with a really acidic nettley bite.
4 Hazy reddy copper, brief frothy head. The bottle had just done a baltic crossing and a trek across town, so was a bit shaken up.
8 Lovely lambic, reminds me of cuvee de ranke, some honey notes. Sharp light berries, gooseberry, and that delicious aged woody butteriness. No hint of 8% at all.
5 Initial massively sharp bite, real sourness, not hiding behind any sugar at all. Only in the finish does a warm sweet spirit hang around, but its soft like honey.
15 Best Faro ever. A world class lambic that stands up well against any lambic style.
(bottled and shared with fatphil) nice amber colour with no head. dry and thick. best faro ever
Bottle.Dark orange colour with small white head.Aroma is sourish with frutiy  taste.Flavor of horseblanket and barnyard fruity with hint of wood (harpiks) nice slight dry finish.

bottle @ kerstbierfestival 
head: beige, away fast 
smell: grainy bread, geueze, malts, yeast, citric, oaky features, sour, bit of biterness, bit of vanilla 
taste: sour malty start , champagne like biterness , sour oaky/wooden , palate, afterwards, nice amount of fruits and touch of vanilla and olives great beer, but i wouldnt state this as a faro ...

Cloudy orange with a small white head. Complex aroma of funk, grass, tobacco, wood and tannin. Dry and tart flavour with green tobacco, caramel, tannin. I dont know how it ended up as a faro, but there is more acidity than most geuzes and the complexity is just amazing

A: The pour is quite dark, an amber sort of color with a fair amount of brown notes. The head is rather large and off-white in color.

S: The nose is only mildly funky, for a Drie Fonteinen beer, anyway. A very slight hint of their usual sweaty sock aroma along with some grass and earth. Quite a bit of sweet candi sugar like aroma, which I was not expecting at all. And there are lots of fruit notes to this beer as well.

T: A fairly aggressive grassy quality comes through on the palate, as well as some straw. The tartness is there, but only a slight lactic/lemon character to the beer overall. Again, the fruity sweetness shows itself, but it provides a very interesting contrast.

January 25th, 2008 Bottling Date, Best by January 2012; Sampled October 2010
A soft pour into my large Tripel Karmeliet tulip produces a two-finger thick, lightly amber-tinged, tan colored head. The beer is a dark amber color that shows a hazed (despite sitting in the fridge for a month or two), plum, light amber with gold highlighted hue when held up to the light. The aroma smells tart and fruity up front and really reminds me of plums with a caramelized apple backdrop to it. There is a certain mustiness to it as well as some damp, barnyard aged, musky cloth blanket notes, perhaps a touch of phenolics / acetone and a certain spiciness that I cant quite tell if it comes from acetic acid or not. I poured some for my wife in a 25cl tulip glass and a note of overly-ripe cheese and perhaps a touch of rotting fruit aromatics even, or is that a rotting vegetable like note (baby puke even :-).

Dry tasting up front, but quite carbonated, though it doesnt get very fizzy as the body of this brew is quite thick (at least if you were expecting something Lambic like in texture). Woody oak notes and a touch of spiciness show the barrel influence. This is actually quite dry, which is quite a shock if you were to believe the Faro designation this has been getting; there is not much of any residual sugar as all the Candi-sugar has been fermented out completely. The darker malts used (the label mentions Munich malt and amber malt) add some nice malt character to the finish; it is subtle underneath the more dominant Lambic-like character, but provides finishing touches of biscuit-like malt, a touch of toasty whole grain character as well as a chewy brown bread crumb (crumb being the part of the bread inside the crust and not crumbled dried bread) notes. Nicely tart tasting, but it is not nearly as bracingly tart as one would expect from a regular strength Lambic (extra alcohol does tend to inhibit lactic acid production) and the acidity couples with some phenolic notes to produce some light spiciness in the finish that intermingles with the spicy oak notes. A touch of vanillin character is contributed by the oak aging and maybe even a hint of coconut. I do like the texture of this beer, the ample, but not over-whelming carbonation mixes quite well with the medium texture that has a certain creaminess to it. Perhaps a hint of sweetness comes through as this warms up, but really it comes through as a boost to the fruitiness rather than as an actual sweetness; notes of plum, fragrant apples (like Macintosh) and perhaps a hint of caramelized melon are just barely noticeable.

This is not in the least a Faro, and was badly characterized as such as a beer brewed with Candi-sugar that has been fermented is entirely different than one sweetened by such for serving; this is made even more ridiculous when you consider this was bottled in 2008 and released in 2010, you could never reasonably do this with a Faro. This is not over-carbonated yet, and I dont really see this being a future problem for this beer; there is very little residual sugar left here and I would guess that this will age gracefully well past the January 2012 best by date. This is a nice alternative to a lighter Lambic / Gueuze, definitely a bit more appropriate for the winter time, though this is certainly not heavy, but I am not sure that I would ever choose this over a more traditional Lambic. Worthwhile as an experiment, but I cant see myself stocking up on this particular batch; with the variation between batches and given this is a first time thing, if future batches took a different turn than this has it might be worth picking up those; I wouldnt mind if there was more lactic acidity and perhaps even more character from the darker malt or even the candi-sugar.
